summary: This document is an exhibit containing an email from a prosecutor discussing potential charges against Jeffrey Epstein and a draft plea agreement. The email reveals internal debate about charging an alleged victim as a perpetrator and explores using conspiracy charges for older acts. The attached plea agreement outlines Epstein's guilty plea to federal charges of violating a child victim's privacy and simple assault, with a joint sentencing recommendation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central defendant in the criminal case, agreeing to plead guilty to charges of violating a child victim's privacy and simple assault as outlined in the attached plea agreement.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who signs the plea agreement on behalf of the United States government.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein's defense attorney, who is copied on the initial email and signs the plea agreement on behalf of the defendant.

connections.description: Lefkowitz is identified as the attorney for defendant Jeffrey Epstein, representing him in the plea negotiations and signing the agreement.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, is the prosecuting authority entering into a plea agreement with defendant Epstein.

events.title: Privacy Violation Offense
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is charged with knowingly and intentionally violating the privacy protection accorded to a child victim, Jane Doe #1.

events.title: Assault on Aircraft
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is charged with committing a simple assault on a person over age 16 while on an aircraft owned by a U.S. citizen in flight over the high seas.

events.title: Alleged Underage Travel
events.description: Prosecutor references hearsay evidence that a young woman traveled on Epstein's airplane when she was under 18, around 2000 or 2001, which is outside the statute of limitations.

keyFacts: Prosecutors considered but faced 'negative reaction' to charging an assault with a specific individual as the victim because she was 'considered one of the main perpetrators of the offenses' they planned to charge.

The proposed federal plea deal involved Epstein pleading guilty to two charges: violating a child victim's privacy (18 U.S.C. ยง 403) and simple assault on a person over 16 on an aircraft (18 U.S.C. ยง 113(a)(5)).
The parties agreed to jointly recommend a sentence of 18 months' imprisonment, 2 years of supervised release, and a $200,000 fine for the federal charges.

Epstein also agreed to plead guilty to a state charge of solicitation of minors to engage in prostitution, with a binding joint recommendation for a 30-month sentence (20 months prison, 10 months community control).
The U.S. agreed to provide Epstein's attorneys with a list of identified victims (not to exceed 40) after sentencing and to appoint a guardian ad litem for them.
